I think I messed up a little bit.

I wanted something,
say something different. [laughter]
Hi, my name is Jung Koo Kang.

I'm an assistant professor
in the Accounting and Management Unit
at Harvard Business School.

I study how financial technologies
and alternative data

collected from nontraditional sources
can drive innovation, particularly

in credit markets; and how can they create
value for businesses and benefit
individual borrowers.

Financial technologies
have the potential to address

critical social problems such as financial
exclusion and wealth inequality.
On the other hand,

if they are not properly used,
they can exacerbate these problems.

Therefore, it is important to understand
how we can better design and structure

these new financial products
so that they can create more value
and benefit to society.

I'm mostly excited
about potential research

opportunities on this topic
because these financial technologies

also produce new data
that allow researchers

to create noble measures
and study important questions.

For instance,
I worked with a digital lender to study

how having access to digital credit
can enhance

financial welfare of people
in a developing economy.

So we obtained their data collected
from mobile devices that include texts,

contact lists, and GPS information
to measure

individual wealth of these people
without having
any financial records.

I brought this piece of paper
with a circle drawn on it

because I hope to have the characteristics
that I find in this circle.

That are: well-rounded, easy
going , and consistent.

Regardless of how you look at this circle
it has the same shape.
And also, I try to be open minded

and listen
to otherâ€™s thoughts and opinions,
and be flexible in my own thinking.
These are the traits that I want to embody

and hopefully they can better
describe me in the future.
